ComicInfo.Summary:
Editorial staff of MAD (listed in sequence 6) depicted as monkeys and apes.
Various short satires of pop culture, and of the Fundalini Pages.
Monkey solves a crime using a combination of deductive reasoning and chimpanzee habits.
Monkeys and apes making people look foolish.
Parodies of these famous works of art using monkeys and apes instead of humans: David, by Monkeyangelo; Gorilla With A Pearl Earring, by Banannas Vermeer; Whistler's Monkey; The Screech, by Edvard Munkee. Presented as the Winter/Spring Catalogue of The Museum Of Monkey Art (MOMA).
Answers monkeys and apes might give to stupid questions asked of them.
Unknown monkeys who helped make American history, from the Mayflower to the Woodstock concert.
The Black Monkey tries to ruin a trap set by the White Monkey, but gets caught anyway.
Parody of eHarmony ad...for monkeys.
The foolishness of thinking monkeys can affect the planet's environment.
An orangutan shows how to draw.
Parody of a Banana Republic catalog, with fashions modeled by chimpanzees, doing things chimpanzees would do.
ComicInfo.Tags: Fantabulamonkey,Bittermonkey,Black Spy,White Spy,Albert Einstein,Charles Darwin,Alfred E. Neuman
ComicInfo.Title: Meet The New Staff of MAD; The Monkey-Lini Pages; MONKey; A MAD Look at Humans; MOMA; Snappy Answers To Stupid Human Questions; Great Monkeys In American History; Spyder Monkey vs. Spyder Monkey; eHarmonkey; The Strip Club; 10 Things You, As A Concerned Monkey, Can Do To Save The Environment; How To Draw A Monkey; Bananas Republic Summer 2008; Drawn-Out Dramas
